title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Why was Denis Diderot imprisoned in 1749?

options.label: A
options.text: For writing a pornographic novel.

options.label: B
options.text: For translating and tutoring without permission.

options.label: C
options.text: For writing an essay about a philosopher's deathbed rejection of God.

options.label: D
options.text: For authoring sermons for priests.

multiple-choice.question: What was the original project assigned to Denis Diderot by publisher Andr√© le Breton?

options.label: A
options.text: To create an original encyclopedia covering all knowledge.

options.label: B
options.text: To adapt the English cyclopedia for French subscribers.

options.label: C
options.text: To write a pornographic novel.

options.label: D
options.text: To author sermons for priests.

multiple-choice.question: Who was the co-editor paired with Denis Diderot for the encyclopedia project?

options.label: A
options.text: Jean Jacques Rousseau.

options.label: B
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert.

options.label: C
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt.

options.label: D
options.text: Voltaire.

multiple-choice.question: How did Denis Diderot organize the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: Alphabetically by subject.

options.label: B
options.text: Using Francis Bacon's "Classification of Knowledge" into a three-part system.

options.label: C
options.text: By the importance of each entry.

options.label: D
options.text: By the length of each entry.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Jean Jacques Rousseau's contribution to the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: He wrote the famous preliminary discourse.

options.label: B
options.text: He wrote much of the music section and an entry on political economy.

options.label: C
options.text: He wrote a quarter of the encyclopedia.

options.label: D
options.text: He contributed entries on history, elegance, and fire.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Louis de Jaucourt's book on anatomy?

options.label: A
options.text: It was published and became a bestseller.

options.label: B
options.text: It was censored and never published.

options.label: C
options.text: The ship carrying the manuscript sank.

options.label: D
options.text: It was lost in a fire.

multiple-choice.question: Why was the encyclopedia banned by King Louis XV and Pope Clement XIII?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was written in French.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was considered "dangerous" and "reprehensible".

options.label: C
options.text: Because it contained recipes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was too long.

multiple-choice.question: How did Denis Diderot manage to continue publishing the encyclopedia despite the ban?

options.label: A
options.text: He smuggled proofs outside France for publication.

options.label: B
options.text: He hid his papers at his own house.

options.label: C
options.text: He stopped writing and gave up on the project.

options.label: D
options.text: He changed the content to appease the authorities.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the encyclopedia in the context of the French Enlightenment?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a cornerstone of the Enlightenment and a testament to France's crisis of authority.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a collection of recipes and crafts.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a technical dictionary with no broader impact.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a work of fiction with no historical significance.

multiple-choice.question: What is notable about Diderot's entry on the plant aguaxima?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a detailed scientific description.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a recipe for cooking the plant.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an example of Diderot's sense of humor and humanity.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a philosophical treatise on the nature of plants.

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor that determines how quickly a person's skin responds to ultraviolet sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: Skin texture

options.label: B
options.text: Skin color

options.label: C
options.text: Age

options.label: D
options.text: Genetics

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the pigment that gives skin and hair its color?

options.label: A
options.text: Melatonin

options.label: B
options.text: Melanin

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D

options.label: D
options.text: Keratin

multiple-choice.question: What are the two basic forms of melanin?

options.label: A
options.text: Eumelanin and pheomelanin

options.label: B
options.text: Melanin and keratin

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D and melanin

options.label: D
options.text: Eumelanin and melanin

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of melanin in the skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce vitamin D

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the skin from UV damage

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To produce hormones

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the deadly cancer that can form in the skin's melanocytes due to UV damage?

options.label: A
options.text: Melanoma

options.label: B
options.text: Skin cancer

options.label: C
options.text: Sunburn

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D deficiency

multiple-choice.question: How did our ancestors adapt to the intense UV radiation near the Equator?

options.label: A
options.text: By developing lighter skin

options.label: B
options.text: By developing darker skin

options.label: C
options.text: By using sunscreen

options.label: D
options.text: By avoiding the sun

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of UV light for the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: It damages skin cells

options.label: B
options.text: It produces vitamin D

options.label: C
options.text: It causes sunburn

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to melanoma

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition that can occur due to a lack of vitamin D?

options.label: A
options.text: Rickets

options.label: B
options.text: Melanoma

options.label: C
options.text: Sunburn

options.label: D
options.text: Skin cancer

multiple-choice.question: Why did skin color in regions with less sunlight gradually lighten over time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because lighter skin was more resistant to UV damage

options.label: B
options.text: Because lighter skin was better at producing vitamin D

options.label: C
options.text: Because darker skin was more resistant to UV damage

options.label: D
options.text: Because darker skin was better at producing vitamin D

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion about skin color based on the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Skin color determines a person's character

options.label: B
options.text: Skin color is an adaptive trait for living on Earth

options.label: C
options.text: Skin color is determined by genetics

options.label: D
options.text: Skin color is a fixed trait that does not change over time

title: How to speak so that people want to listen

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary concern regarding the way people communicate?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are too loud when speaking.

options.label: B
options.text: That people are too quiet when speaking.

options.label: C
options.text: That people are not being heard effectively when speaking.

options.label: D
options.text: That people are speaking too quickly.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are the "seven deadly sins of speaking"?

options.label: A
options.text: Gossip, judging, negativity, complaining, excuses, embroidery, and dogmatism.

options.label: B
options.text: Speaking too loudly, speaking too quietly, speaking too quickly, speaking too slowly, using jargon, using slang, and using sarcasm.

options.label: C
options.text: Not making eye contact, not using body language, not varying tone of voice, not using pauses, not using rhetorical devices, not being clear, and not being concise.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a monotone voice, using a high-pitched voice, using a low-pitched voice, speaking with a lisp, speaking with a stutter, speaking too formally, and speaking too informally.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "hail" in the context of effective communication?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of precipitation.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of greeting someone enthusiastically.

options.label: C
options.text: An acronym for honesty, authenticity, integrity, and love.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of vocal exercise.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the importance of honesty in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows people to be deceitful and manipulative.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps people to build trust and credibility with others.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not important in communication.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important in formal communication.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the role of love in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not necessary in communication.

options.label: B
options.text: It is only necessary in romantic relationships.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to temper honesty and make communication more effective.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most important aspect of communication.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on how to improve one's communication skills?

options.label: A
options.text: To practice speaking in front of a mirror.

options.label: B
options.text: To record oneself speaking and listen to the recording.

options.label: C
options.text: To warm up one's voice before speaking and to use various vocal techniques such as register, timbre, prosody, pace, pitch, and volume.

options.label: D
options.text: To read books on communication and attend seminars.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the importance of register in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to convey authority and power.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to convey friendliness and approachability.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not important in communication.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important in formal communication.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the role of prosody in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not important in communication.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to convey meaning and add emphasis to words.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only important in formal communication.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important in informal communication.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the importance of silence in communication?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not important in communication.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to convey boredom and disinterest.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to add emphasis and create a sense of drama.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only important in formal communication.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for a world where people communicate effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: A world where people are constantly arguing and debating.

options.label: B
options.text: A world where people are not listening to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: A world where people are creating sound consciously and consuming sound consciously and designing all environments consciously for sound.

options.label: D
options.text: A world where people are only communicating through technology.

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession, and how long has she been in the education field?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker is a doctor and has been in the field for 20 years.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker is a teacher and has been in the field for 40 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker is a lawyer and has been in the field for 30 years.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker is a scientist and has been in the field for 10 years.

multiple-choice.question: According to James Comer, what is necessary for significant learning to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: A significant amount of homework.

options.label: B
options.text: A significant relationship.

options.label: C
options.text: A significant amount of technology.

options.label: D
options.text: A significant amount of testing.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker's colleague say about her approach to teaching?

options.label: A
options.text: "They pay me to build relationships with kids."

options.label: B
options.text: "They don't pay me to like the kids. They pay me to teach a lesson."

options.label: C
options.text: "I only teach kids who are well-behaved."

options.label: D
options.text: "I only teach kids who are smart."

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker do when she realized she had taught a lesson incorrectly?

options.label: A
options.text: She ignored the mistake and moved on.

options.label: B
options.text: She apologized to the students and corrected the mistake.

options.label: C
options.text: She blamed the students for not understanding the lesson.

options.label: D
options.text: She gave the students extra homework as punishment.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's approach to raising the self-esteem of her students?

options.label: A
options.text: She told them they were not smart enough.

options.label: B
options.text: She told them they were the best students and she was the best teacher.

options.label: C
options.text: She ignored their self-esteem and focused on academics.

options.label: D
options.text: She gave them extra homework to build their confidence.

multiple-choice.question: What phrase did the speaker have her students repeat to build their confidence?

options.label: A
options.text: "I am nobody. I will never be anybody."

options.label: B
options.text: "I am somebody. I was somebody when I came. I'll be a better somebody when I leave."

options.label: C
options.text: "I am smart. I am capable. I am strong."

options.label: D
options.text: "I am stupid. I am weak. I am nobody."

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker respond to a student who missed 18 out of 20 questions on a quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: She gave him an F and told him he was a failure.

options.label: B
options.text: She gave him a +2 and a smiley face and encouraged him to do better.

options.label: C
options.text: She ignored his score and moved on to the next student.

options.label: D
options.text: She gave him extra homework as punishment.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker's mother do to help her students who were struggling?

options.label: A
options.text: She ignored them and focused on the smarter students.

options.label: B
options.text: She gave them extra homework to help them catch up.

options.label: C
options.text: She took the time to review with them, made home visits, and provided them with basic necessities.

options.label: D
options.text: She told them they were not smart enough and should give up.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker say about the importance of relationships in teaching?

options.label: A
options.text: Relationships are not important in teaching.

options.label: B
options.text: Relationships are only important for certain students.

options.label: C
options.text: Relationships are the key to successful teaching and learning.

options.label: D
options.text: Relationships are only important for teachers, not students.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker say every child deserves?

options.label: A
options.text: A failing grade to teach them a lesson.

options.label: B
options.text: A champion who will never give up on them.

options.label: C
options.text: A teacher who ignores them and focuses on smarter students.

options.label: D
options.text: A school that is poorly funded and lacks resources.

options.label: A
options.text: Respiration

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Decomposition

options.label: D
options.text: Fermentation

options.text: Saturn

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Transpiration

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Isaac Newton

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How to make your writing funnier - Cheri Steinkellner

multiple-choice.question: What are the basic ingredients of great storytelling, including comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Who, what, when, where

options.label: B
options.text: Why, how, and to whom

options.label: C
options.text: Who, what, when, where, why, and how

options.label: D
options.text: What, where, why, and to whom

multiple-choice.question: According to the Commedia rule, how can you create comic characters?

options.label: A
options.text: Find the strength and play it down

options.label: B
options.text: Find the flaw and play it up

options.label: C
options.text: Find the weakness and play it safe

options.label: D
options.text: Find the uniqueness and play it cool

multiple-choice.question: What is the surprise or incongruity theory of humor?

options.label: A
options.text: We laugh at things that seem ordinary and expected

options.label: B
options.text: We laugh at things that seem out of place or run up against our expectations

options.label: C
options.text: We laugh at things that seem funny and humorous

options.label: D
options.text: We laugh at things that seem boring and uninteresting

multiple-choice.question: What is a fun way to find incongruities in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: By drawing conclusions

options.label: B
options.text: By drawing connections with a mind map

options.label: C
options.text: By drawing inspiration from others

options.label: D
options.text: By drawing from personal experiences

multiple-choice.question: How can you generate comedic material by shifting from observation to imagination?

options.label: A
options.text: By going from "what is" to "what was"

options.label: B
options.text: By going from "what is" to "what if"

options.label: C
options.text: By going from "what if" to "what is"

options.label: D
options.text: By going from "what was" to "what is"

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule of three, or zig zig zag, in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Setting up an expected pattern and then repeating it

options.label: B
options.text: Setting up an expected pattern and then flipping it

options.label: C
options.text: Setting up an unexpected pattern and then repeating it

options.label: D
options.text: Setting up an unexpected pattern and then flipping it

multiple-choice.question: What is the punchline rule in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Put your punch at the beginning of the line

options.label: B
options.text: Put your punch in the middle of the line

options.label: C
options.text: Put your punch at the end of the line

options.label: D
options.text: Put your punch anywhere in the line

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule of K in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Words with a k-sound are considered serious

options.label: B
options.text: Words with a k-sound are considered comical

options.label: C
options.text: Words with a k-sound are considered boring

options.label: D
options.text: Words with a k-sound are considered uninteresting

multiple-choice.question: Why is humor subjective in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because everyone has the same sense of humor

options.label: B
options.text: Because everyone has a different sense of humor

options.label: C
options.text: Because humor is based on facts

options.label: D
options.text: Because humor is based on opinions

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important rule of writing funny?

options.label: A
options.text: Have a good sense of humor

options.label: B
options.text: Have a good understanding of comedy

options.label: C
options.text: Have fun

options.label: D
options.text: Have a good knowledge of writing

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the human cell line that was the first to be grown in a lab and has been used extensively in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: HeLa cells

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer cells

options.label: C
options.text: Stem cells

options.label: D
options.text: Immortal cells

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists grow human cells in the lab?

options.label: A
options.text: To study how cells function and understand how diseases develop

options.label: B
options.text: To test new treatments on patients

options.label: C
options.text: To create new diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how the human body works

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the tumor sample received by George Gey in 1951?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a typical sample of cancer cells

options.label: B
options.text: It was a sample of stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: Its cells just kept dividing and thriving

options.label: D
options.text: It was a sample of dead cells

multiple-choice.question: Who was Henrietta Lacks, and what was her contribution to science?

options.label: A
options.text: She was a scientist who discovered the HeLa cell line

options.label: B
options.text: She was a patient whose tumor cells were used to create the HeLa cell line

options.label: C
options.text: She was a doctor who treated cancer patients

options.label: D
options.text: She was a researcher who worked with George Gey

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when normal human cells self-destruct after a certain number of divisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Apoptosis

options.label: B
options.text: Mitosis

options.label: C
options.text: Meiosis

options.label: D
options.text: Cell division

multiple-choice.question: Why are HeLa cells special, and what allows them to survive when other cell lines die?

options.label: A
options.text: They have built-in control mechanisms that prevent genetic errors

options.label: B
options.text: They ignore signals to self-destruct and divide indefinitely

options.label: C
options.text: They are immune to diseases

options.label: D
options.text: The reason is not entirely known

multiple-choice.question: How have HeLa cells been used in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: To study diseases such as polio, measles, and HIV

options.label: B
options.text: To test new treatments on patients

options.label: C
options.text: To create new diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how the human body works

multiple-choice.question: What was discovered about human cells using HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They have 23 chromosomes

options.label: B
options.text: They have 46 chromosomes

options.label: C
options.text: They have 80 chromosomes

options.label: D
options.text: They have 100 chromosomes

multiple-choice.question: What enzyme was discovered in HeLa cells that helps cancer cells evade destruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomerase

options.label: B
options.text: Apoptase

options.label: C
options.text: Mitase

options.label: D
options.text: Cellulase

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the significant discoveries made possible by HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: That cervical cancer can be caused by a virus called HPV

options.label: B
options.text: That cancer is a genetic disease

options.label: C
options.text: That stem cells can cure diseases

options.label: D
options.text: That human cells are immortal

title: Zika Virus Spreading in Most of the Americas

title: #TEDEdChat: A Math Class Makeover | Dan Meyer |

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's occupation?

options.label: A
options.text: Math researcher

options.label: B
options.text: High school math teacher

options.label: C
options.text: Math textbook author

options.label: D
options.text: Education policy maker

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main issue with math education in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of funding

options.label: B
options.text: Insufficient teacher training

options.label: C
options.text: The way math is taught does not promote patient problem-solving

options.label: D
options.text: Math is not a required subject

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's definition of "math reasoning"?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to memorize and apply formulas

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to solve problems quickly and accurately

options.label: C
options.text: The application of math processes to the world around us

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to solve word problems

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Students lack initiative and perseverance

options.label: C
options.text: Students are too focused on getting the right answer

options.label: D
options.text: Students are not using enough technology

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's approach to teaching math, as opposed to traditional methods?

options.label: A
options.text: Focus on memorization and repetition

options.label: B
options.text: Use of multimedia and real-world examples

options.label: C
options.text: Emphasis on individual work and competition

options.label: D
options.text: Use of textbooks and worksheets

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think that traditional math textbooks are not effective?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive

options.label: B
options.text: They are too easy

options.label: C
options.text: They provide too much information and do not require students to think critically

options.label: D
options.text: They are too boring

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of using multimedia in math education?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes math more fun and engaging

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a level playing field for students of different skill levels

options.label: C
options.text: It allows students to learn at their own pace

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for his students?

options.label: A
options.text: To become math experts

options.label: B
options.text: To be able to solve problems quickly and accurately

options.label: C
options.text: To develop patient problem-solving skills and math reasoning

options.label: D
options.text: To get good grades

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think that this is an amazing time to be a math teacher?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the abundance of resources and technology available

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the emphasis on standardized testing

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the lack of qualified math teachers

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the simplicity of math curriculum

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on memorization and repetition in math education

options.label: B
options.text: To use more technology in math education

options.label: C
options.text: To insist on better math curriculum that promotes patient problem-solving

options.label: D

title: Why certain wildfires are necessary - Jim Schulz

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Human error

options.label: D
options.text: Animal behavior

options.label: B
options.text: It gave them the ability to cook food and clear land

options.label: C
options.text: It provided a source of entertainment

options.label: D
options.text: It helped them to communicate with each other

options.label: B

title: Can you solve the temple riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: What is the situation that the expedition team finds themselves in at the beginning of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: They have discovered a hidden treasure and are trying to escape the temple.

options.label: B
options.text: They have triggered a trap and must find a way out of the temple before it collapses.

options.label: C
options.text: They are trying to decipher the inscriptions on the walls of the temple.

options.label: D
options.text: They are exploring a new room in the temple.

multiple-choice.question: How many students are accompanying the expedition leader, and what is the problem with two of them?

options.label: A
options.text: There are 8 students, and two of them are injured.

options.label: B
options.text: There are 8 students, and two of them are possessed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen.

options.label: C
options.text: There are 10 students, and two of them are lost.

options.label: D
options.text: There are 12 students, and two of them are arguing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the curse that has affected two of the students, and how does it manifest?

options.label: A
options.text: The curse causes the students to become violent and attack the others.

options.label: B
options.text: The curse causes the students to become lost and disoriented.

options.label: C
options.text: The curse causes the students to lie and deceive the others, but only occasionally.

options.label: D
options.text: The curse causes the students to become trapped in the temple.

multiple-choice.question: How does the expedition leader plan to ensure that everyone escapes the temple?

options.label: A
options.text: By sending one person to explore each of the four halls ahead.

options.label: B
options.text: By sending groups of four students down two of the paths.

options.label: C
options.text: By sending one pair and two trios of students to explore the remaining three paths.

options.label: D
options.text: By having everyone stay together and try to find the exit as a group.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the expedition leader's plan involve splitting the students into groups of different sizes?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that everyone has a chance to explore each of the four halls.

options.label: B
options.text: To minimize the risk of the possessed students affecting the outcome.

options.label: C
options.text: To maximize the chances of finding the exit quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: To make it easier to identify which students are possessed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key insight that the expedition leader uses to ensure the success of the plan?

options.label: A
options.text: That the possessed students will always lie.

options.label: B
options.text: That the possessed students will always tell the truth.

options.label: C
options.text: That there are only two possessed students, and the other six will always tell the truth.

options.label: D
options.text: That the temple will collapse in exactly one hour.

multiple-choice.question: How does the expedition leader plan to determine which path is the correct one?

options.label: A
options.text: By trusting the majority opinion of each group.

options.label: B
options.text: By trusting the opinion of the pair of students.

options.label: C
options.text: By using the process of elimination to figure out which path is correct.

options.label: D
options.text: By having each group explore each of the four halls.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three possible outcomes when the groups return to the hall, and how does the expedition leader plan to handle each one?

options.label: A
options.text: The groups may all agree, or one or two groups may disagree.

options.label: B
options.text: The groups may all disagree, or one or two groups may agree.

options.label: C
options.text: The expedition leader will trust the majority opinion in each case.

options.label: D
options.text: The expedition leader will ignore the opinion of the pair of students.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the temple and the students at the end of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The temple collapses, and the students are trapped.

options.label: B
options.text: The temple collapses, but the students escape safely.

options.label: C
options.text: The temple is saved, and the students are rewarded.

options.label: D
options.text: The temple is abandoned, and the students go home.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final outcome for the two students who were possessed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen?

options.label: A
options.text: They are trapped in the temple forever.

options.label: B
options.text: They are freed from the curse and escape with the others.

options.label: C
options.text: They are punished for their deception.

options.label: D
options.text: They are left behind to explore the temple further.

title: The most lightning-struck place on Earth - Graeme Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What was Sir Francis Drake's plan when he sailed across the Gulf of Venezuela in 1595?

options.label: A
options.text: To explore the nearby Lake Maracaibo and discover its natural wonders.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a new English colony in the region.

options.label: C
options.text: To overthrow the Spanish settlers living in the colony near Lake Maracaibo.

options.label: D
options.text: To trade with the local population and establish new commercial routes.

multiple-choice.question: What natural phenomenon foiled Sir Francis Drake's plan to overthrow the Spanish settlers?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive earthquake that destroyed his fleet.

options.label: B
options.text: Huge flashes of lightning that illuminated the landscape, exposing his fleet.

options.label: C
options.text: A severe storm that forced him to retreat.

options.label: D
options.text: A dense fog that made navigation impossible.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about Lake Maracaibo in terms of weather patterns?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the driest place on Earth, with very little rainfall throughout the year.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the stormiest place on the planet, with thunderstorms raging above it for up to 200 days of the year.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a very stable and predictable climate, with little variation in temperature and precipitation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the coldest place on Earth, with extremely low temperatures throughout the year.

multiple-choice.question: What causes lightning to form in storm clouds?

options.label: A
options.text: The movement of tectonic plates in the Earth's crust.

options.label: B
options.text: The buildup of opposing electrical charges within the cloud or between the cloud and the Earth below.

options.label: C
options.text: The release of heat from the Earth's core.

options.label: D
options.text: The interaction between the Earth's magnetic field and the solar wind.

multiple-choice.question: How often does lightning strike the Earth, on average?

options.label: A
options.text: About 1,000 times per year.

options.label: B
options.text: About 100,000 times per year.

options.label: C
options.text: About 350 million times per year.

options.label: D
options.text: About 1 billion times per year.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the frequency with which lightning flashes in a square kilometer?

options.label: A
options.text: Lightning density.

options.label: B
options.text: Storm intensity.

options.label: C
options.text: Weather pattern.

options.label: D
options.text: Climate index.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about Lake Maracaibo's lightning density?

options.label: A
options.text: It has the lowest lightning density of any place on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: It has an average lightning density, comparable to other places on Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: It has the highest lightning density of any place on Earth, with an average of 250 strikes per square kilometer.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a highly variable lightning density, with some areas experiencing much more lightning than others.

multiple-choice.question: What factors contribute to Lake Maracaibo's high lightning density?

options.label: A
options.text: Its location near the Equator, the warm waters of the Caribbean, and the surrounding mountain ranges.

options.label: B
options.text: Its location in a region of high volcanic activity, the presence of a large river, and the surrounding desert landscape.

options.label: C
options.text: Its location in a region of high population density, the presence of a large city, and the surrounding industrial activity.

options.label: D
options.text: Its location in a region of low atmospheric pressure, the presence of a large lake, and the surrounding forest landscape.

multiple-choice.question: How do sailors use the intense lightning storms at Lake Maracaibo to their advantage?

options.label: A
options.text: They avoid the area altogether, due to the danger posed by the storms.

options.label: B
options.text: They use the storms as a natural source of energy to power their ships.

options.label: C
options.text: They use the lightning as a natural lighthouse to illuminate their path across the seas.

options.label: D
options.text: They use the storms as a means of navigation, relying on the winds and currents to guide their ships.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the phenomenon of the intense lightning storms at Lake Maracaibo?

options.label: A
options.text: The Maracaibo Storm.

options.label: B
options.text: The Maracaibo Beacon.

options.label: C
options.text: The Maracaibo Lightning Display.

options.label: D
options.text: The Maracaibo Weather Pattern.

title: How science fiction can help predict the future - Roey Tzezana

multiple-choice.question: What do futurists do?

options.label: A
options.text: They analyze past events to understand the present.

options.label: B
options.text: They forecast the future by analyzing movements and trends in society.

options.label: C
options.text: They develop new technologies to shape the future.

options.label: D
options.text: They make decisions for policymakers and world leaders.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way futurists arrive at their predictions?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing the past and its patterns.

options.label: B
options.text: By consulting with scientists and industry leaders.

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing movements and trends in society and charting their paths into the future.

options.label: D
options.text: By using magic and intuition.

multiple-choice.question: What did the RAND Corporation's consultation with scientists and futurists in the mid-20th century achieve?

options.label: A
options.text: They predicted the invention of the internet.

options.label: B
options.text: They forecast many of the technologies we take for granted today, including artificial organs and birth control pills.

options.label: C
options.text: They developed a new form of literature called science fiction.

options.label: D
options.text: They created a new think tank to analyze future trends.

multiple-choice.question: According to Arthur C. Clarke, what is a characteristic of sufficiently advanced technology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is easily understandable by anyone.

options.label: B
options.text: It is indistinguishable from magic.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only accessible to a select few.

options.label: D
options.text: It is always predictable.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to prepare for a future that will be as magical to us as our present would appear to someone from the 19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: By relying solely on modern technology and data analysis techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: By exploring fantastic scenarios through science fiction.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring the possibilities of future technological advancements.

options.label: D
options.text: By predicting the future with absolute certainty.

multiple-choice.question: What did Aldous Huxley predict in his book "Brave New World"?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the internet.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of antidepressants.

options.label: C
options.text: The development of artificial organs.

options.label: D
options.text: The discovery of an alien civilization.

multiple-choice.question: What did Ray Bradbury predict in his book "Fahrenheit 451"?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the smartphone.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of earbuds, or "thimble radios."

options.label: C
options.text: The development of a way for humans and animals to communicate flawlessly.

options.label: D
options.text: The discovery of an alien civilization.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of science fiction in thinking about the future?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a way to predict the future with absolute certainty.

options.label: B
options.text: It serves as a useful tool for thinking outside of the box and considering radical shifts in familiar institutions.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only used for entertainment purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way to ignore the possibilities of future technological advancements.

multiple-choice.question: What is the project iKnow, and what does it propose?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a project that aims to develop new technologies, and it proposes scenarios such as the discovery of an alien civilization.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a project that aims to predict the future with absolute certainty, and it proposes scenarios such as the development of artificial organs.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a project that employs science fiction writers to propose scenarios such as the discovery of an alien civilization and radical life extension.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a project that ignores the possibilities of future technological advancements.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is our responsibility regarding the future?

options.label: A
options.text: To predict it with absolute certainty.

options.label: B
options.text: To ignore the possibilities of future technological advancements.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine which possibilities we will work towards making a reality.

options.label: D
options.text: To rely solely on modern technology and data analysis techniques.

title: Why are human bodies asymmetrical? - Leo Q. Wan

multiple-choice.question: What is a common association with symmetry in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: Complexity

options.label: B
options.text: Beauty

options.label: C
options.text: Imperfection

options.label: D
options.text: Disorganization

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of asymmetry in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: A perfectly shaped leaf

options.label: B
options.text: A butterfly with intricate patterns mirrored on each wing

options.label: C
options.text: Crabs with one giant pincer claw

options.label: D
options.text: A symmetrical human body

multiple-choice.question: How are most vital organs arranged in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Symmetrically

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetrically

options.label: C
options.text: Randomly

options.label: D
options.text: Identically

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetry syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Organ reversal

options.label: D
options.text: Flipped organs

options.label: A
options.text: The node theory

options.label: B
options.text: The cilia theory

options.label: C
options.text: The gene theory

options.label: D
options.text: The protein theory

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the cilia in the node?

options.label: A
options.text: To sense fluid flow

options.label: B
options.text: To activate specific genes

options.label: C
options.text: To push fluid from the right side to the left

options.label: D
options.text: To make certain proteins

multiple-choice.question: In which organ does asymmetry first appear during embryonic development?

options.label: A
options.text: Heart

options.label: B
options.text: Brain

options.label: C
options.text: Liver

options.label: D
options.text: Lungs

multiple-choice.question: What is the property of biomolecules that contributes to asymmetry?

options.label: A
options.text: Chirality

options.label: B
options.text: Symmetry

options.label: C
options.text: Asymmetry

options.label: D
options.text: Complexity

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of cells exhibiting intrinsic asymmetry?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial colonies growing lacy branches

options.label: B
options.text: Human cells cultured in a ring-shaped boundary

options.label: C
options.text: Proteins having complex asymmetric shapes

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the asymmetry at the molecular level?

options.label: A
options.text: Symmetric cells and organisms

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetric cells, embryos, and organisms

options.label: C
options.text: Random arrangement of organs

options.label: D
options.text: Identical mirror images

title: When will the next mass extinction occur? - Borths, D'Emic, and Pritchard

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred about 66 million years ago that had a devastating impact on life on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive earthquake struck the Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: A massive volcanic eruption filled the atmosphere with carbon dioxide.

options.label: C
options.text: An asteroid roughly the size of Manhattan struck the Earth and massive volcanic eruptions filled the atmosphere with carbon dioxide.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's oceans suddenly became acidic.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the world's species disappeared during the mass extinction event that occurred 66 million years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: One-quarter

options.label: B
options.text: One-half

options.label: C
options.text: Three-quarters

options.label: D
options.text: Nine-tenths

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the sudden disappearance of thousands of species in a geological instant?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass migration

options.label: B
options.text: Mass extinction event

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental shift

options.label: D
options.text: Ecological upheaval

multiple-choice.question: What was the largest mass extinction event in Earth's history, and when did it occur?

options.label: A
options.text: The extinction of the dinosaurs, 66 million years ago

options.label: B
options.text: The extinction of 95% of species in the ocean and on land, 252 million years ago

options.label: C
options.text: The extinction of giant ground sloths and mammoths, 10,000 years ago

options.label: D
options.text: The extinction of the Neanderthals, 30,000 years ago

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the supercontinent that formed 252 million years ago, and what was its effect on the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Pangaea, it created many shallow tropical seas and increased biodiversity.

options.label: B
options.text: Pangaea, it eliminated many shallow tropical seas and created deserts.

options.label: C
options.text: Gondwana, it created a massive ice sheet and changed ocean currents.

options.label: D
options.text: Laurasia, it caused a massive greenhouse effect and high temperatures.

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to have contributed to the extinction of giant ground sloths, giant hyenas, and mammoths?

options.label: A
options.text: Climate change and the rise of humans

options.label: B
options.text: The melting of ice caps and changes in ocean currents

options.label: C
options.text: The spread of disease and the introduction of invasive species

options.label: D
options.text: The massive asteroid impact and volcanic eruptions

multiple-choice.question: What is the current rate of extinction compared to the normal background rate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is similar to the normal background rate.

options.label: B
options.text: It is tens of times higher than the normal background rate.

options.label: C
options.text: It is hundreds to thousands of times higher than the normal background rate.

options.label: D
options.text: It is lower than the normal background rate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique ability that makes humans capable of driving mass extinctions, and what can we do to prevent them?

options.label: A
options.text: Our ability to adapt to new environments, and we can prevent extinctions by learning about past events and recognizing what is happening today.

options.label: B
options.text: Our ability to create new tools and methods, and we can prevent extinctions by using this knowledge to lessen our impact on other species.

options.label: C
options.text: Our ability to migrate to new habitats, and we can prevent extinctions by preserving biodiversity.

options.label: D
options.text: Our ability to react to environmental changes, and we can prevent extinctions by becoming more sustainable.

multiple-choice.question: What can we learn from past extinction events, and how can we apply this knowledge to the present?

options.label: A
options.text: We can learn about the causes of extinctions and apply this knowledge to prevent future extinctions.

options.label: B
options.text: We can learn about the effects of climate change and apply this knowledge to mitigate its impacts.

options.label: C
options.text: We can learn about the importance of biodiversity and apply this knowledge to preserve ecosystems.

options.label: D
options.text: We can learn about the role of humans in extinctions and apply this knowledge to become more sustainable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of learning about past extinction events and recognizing what is happening today?

options.label: A
options.text: To transform humanity's impact on the world from something destructive to something collaborative.

options.label: B
options.text: To preserve biodiversity and prevent future extinctions.

options.label: C
options.text: To mitigate the effects of climate change and protect ecosystems.

options.label: D
options.text: To become more sustainable and reduce our impact on the environment.
